{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11774,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Iris sibirica prefers consistently moist soil but does not tolerate standing water for extended periods. The plant thrives in conditions similar to its natural habitat, which are damp meadows and marshes. Water regularly during the growing season, especially in periods of little rainfall. Ensure the soil is well-draining to prevent root rot, and consider using mulch to retain moisture. During winter, the Siberian Iris is generally dormant and requires minimal watering, though it should not dry out completely."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Iris sibirica grows best in full sun to part shade. Ideally, choose a planting location that receives at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight each day. While they can tolerate partial shade, the flowering may be more prolific with higher sun exposure. In hotter climates, some afternoon shade can help prevent the foliage from overheating and maintain soil moisture. Proper sunlight is crucial for healthy growth and abundant flowering, so adjust sunlight exposure based on the plant's vigor and flowering habit."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Iris sibirica involves removing spent blooms and any dead or diseased leaves promptly to maintain plant health and aesthetics. After blooming, cut back the flowering stems close to the ground. In late fall, once the foliage has turned brown, cut it back to about 2-3 inches above the ground. This helps prevent potential overwintering pests and diseases. If the plant seems crowded or less vigorous, you can divide and prune the rhizomes in early spring or late fall to rejuvenate the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Siberian Iris","description":"Iris sibirica (commonly known as Siberian iris or Siberian flag), is a species in the genus Iris. It is a rhizomatous herbaceous perennial, from Europe (including France, Italy, Switzerland, Austria, Czech Republic, Slovakia, Germany, Hungary, Poland, Romania, Bulgaria, Former Yugoslavia, Belarus, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Moldova, Ukraine and northern Turkey) and Central Asia (including Armenia, Azerbaijan and Siberia). It has long green grass-like leaves, tall stem, 2–5 violet-blue, to blue, and occasionally white flowers. It is cultivated...","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["Siberian Iris"],"pest_susceptibility":["Leaf spot","Root rot"],"propagation":["Division","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Iris sibirica"],"soil":["Well-drained","Moist"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10377,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies","Hummingbirds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Salvia mellifera, also known as black sage, is drought-tolerant and requires very little watering once established. In general, it should be watered deeply but infrequently to encourage deep root growth. Water thoroughly during extended periods of heat and drought, but allow the soil to dry out completely between waterings to prevent root rot. During the rainy season or cooler months, reduce watering as the natural rainfall typically suffices. It's essential to use well-draining soil to avoid waterlogging and ensure the plant thrives."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Salvia mellifera thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day for optimal growth and flowering. It can tolerate partial shade, but blooming may be reduced. When planting or situating this shrub, choose a location that receives ample sunlight to support healthy foliage and abundant flowers. If grown indoors or in areas with less natural light, consider supplemental grow lights to mimic its preferred sun exposure. Adequate sunlight also helps in maintaining the plant's compact form and preventing leggy growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Salvia mellifera is important to maintain its shape and encourage healthy growth. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches, and trim back leggy growth to promote bushier growth. Regular pruning can also help in removing spent flower spikes to encourage more blooms and prevent the plant from becoming woody and unruly. Be cautious to not over-prune, as excessive cutting back can stress the plant and reduce flowering."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"black sage","description":"Salvia mellifera (black sage) is a small, highly aromatic, evergreen shrub of the genus Salvia (the sages) native to California, and Baja California, Mexico. It is common in the coastal sage scrub of Southern California and northern Baja California. Black sage has a dark appearance, especially during drought.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["California","Baja California"],"other_name":["black sage"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Salvia mellifera"],"soil":["Well-drained","Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11081,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lamium maculatum prefers consistently moist soil but does not like to sit in waterlogged conditions. To achieve this balance, water the plant thoroughly once the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. During the summer months, when the weather is hot and dry, you might need to water it more frequently. In contrast, reduce the frequency during rainy periods and in the winter. Ensure that the plant is in a well-draining potting mix or garden soil to prevent root rot. Mulching around the plant can help maintain moisture levels and minimize drying out."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lamium maculatum thrives best in partial shade to full shade conditions, making it an excellent choice for areas with limited direct sunlight. While it can tolerate some morning sun, especially in cooler climates, too much direct afternoon sun can cause the leaves to scorch or dry out. In very shaded areas, however, flowering might be reduced. Ideally, provide it with dappled sunlight or filtered light beneath trees or alongside taller plants. For indoor settings, a spot that gets indirect but bright light is suitable. Adapt conditions according to how the plant responds to specific light levels."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lamium maculatum is essential to maintain its shape and encourage dense growth. Regularly trim back any overgrown or leggy stems throughout the growing season to promote bushiness. Deadheading, or removing spent flowers, can extend the blooming period and prevent the plant from self-seeding excessively. In the late fall or early spring, perform a more thorough prune to remove dead or damaged stems, preparing the plant for the new growth cycle. If the plant spreads beyond its desirable boundaries, you can also trim the perimeter to keep it in check."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Spotted deadnettle","description":"Lamium maculatum (also known as spotted dead-nettle, spotted henbit and purple dragon) is a species of flowering plant in the family Lamiaceae, native throughout Europe and temperate Asia (Lebanon, Syria, Turkey, western China).","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["Spotted deadnettle"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Lamium maculatum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10579,"attracts":["Insects"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Drosera filiformis, or the thread-leaf sundew, is a carnivorous plant that thrives in consistently moist conditions. It prefers to be watered with rainwater, distilled, or reverse osmosis water to prevent mineral buildup, as tap water can be harmful. The plant should be kept in a tray of shallow water during its growing season, ensuring the soil remains consistently damp but not waterlogged. In its natural habitat, this plant experiences fluctuating water levels, but for cultivation, aim to provide a stable, damp environment. Allowing the top layer of soil to dry slightly before re-watering can help prevent root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Drosera filiformis thrives in bright, direct sunlight, reflecting its native sunny habitats like open bogs and wetlands. Ideally, it should receive at least 6 hours of full sunlight per day to support healthy growth and good coloration. If natural sunlight is insufficient or inconsistent, especially in indoor environments, supplemental lighting with fluorescent grow lights can be used. Ensure the lighting is close enough to provide adequate intensity without scorching the leaves. Avoid placing the plant in shaded or low-light areas, as this can lead to weak growth and poor coloration."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Drosera filiformis mainly involves the removal of dead or blackened leaves to maintain plant health and appearance. During autumn, when the plant enters dormancy, it may produce a winter bud or \"hibernaculum\". At this time, there is minimal foliage, and any brown or dead parts can be trimmed to prevent mold or disease. Care should be taken not to prune when the plant is actively growing, as this could stress the plant. Proper pruning can encourage new growth and maintain the overall health and vigor of the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Thread-leaved Sundew","description":"Drosera filiformis, commonly known as the thread-leaved sundew, is a small, insectivorous, rosette-forming species of perennial herb. A species of sundew, it is unusual within its genus in that the long, erect, filiform (thread-like) leaves of this plant unroll in spirals – an arrangement similar to the circinate vernation seen in ferns.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Eastern United States"],"other_name":["Thread-leaved Sundew"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal infections"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Drosera filiformis"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10776,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Araucaria columnaris, also known as the Cook Pine, prefers consistently moist soil but is sensitive to overwatering. It is best to water this plant when the top inch of the soil feels dry to the touch. Ensure that the pot or ground where it's planted allows for good drainage to prevent root rot. Reduce the frequency of watering during the colder months, as the plant's growth slows and it requires less moisture. A high humidity environment benefits this pine, so occasional misting can be helpful, especially in drier conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Araucaria columnaris prefers bright, indirect sunlight to thrive, although it can tolerate a few hours of direct morning or late afternoon sun. If grown indoors, place it near a window where it can receive bright light without being exposed to harsh midday sun, which might scorch its needles. Outdoors, they grow well in areas with partial shade, especially in regions with intense sunlight. If grown in low light conditions, the plant may become leggy or exhibit slower growth, signaling a need for more light."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Araucaria columnaris should be minimal and is usually not necessary unless you are shaping the plant. Prune dead or damaged branches to maintain plant health and aesthetics; this can be done at any time of the year. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to make clean cuts and avoid damaging the plant. Be cautious not to remove too many healthy branches, as this can stress the plant. It's also beneficial occasionally to remove lower branches to keep the tree tidy and improve airflow around the trunk."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Cook pine","description":"Araucaria columnaris, the coral reef araucaria, Cook pine, New Caledonia pine, Cook araucaria, or columnar araucaria, is a species of conifer in the family Araucariaceae.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["New Caledonia"],"other_name":["Cook pine"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Araucaria columnaris"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11877,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cassiope mertensiana, commonly known as White Mountain Heather, has moderate watering needs. This plant prefers consistently moist but not waterlogged soil. During the growing season, ensure that the soil is kept evenly damp, especially in dry or hot weather. Avoid letting the soil dry out completely between waterings. In winter, reduce watering slightly, allowing the topsoil to dry out a bit before rewatering. It’s essential to provide good drainage to prevent root rot, so use a well-draining soil mix, preferably one with a good amount of organic matter for optimal moisture retention and aeration."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cassiope mertensiana thrives in full sun to partial shade environments. It requires at least several hours of direct sunlight daily, especially in cooler climates, to encourage healthy growth and abundant flowering. However, in hotter regions, providing some afternoon shade will protect it from scorching. Placing the plant where it receives morning sunlight and afternoon shade can be ideal. While it can tolerate partial shade, insufficient sunlight may lead to leggy growth and fewer blooms, so balancing light exposure according to your local climate is essential for optimal health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Cassiope mertensiana is mainly done to maintain its shape and remove any dead or damaged branches. After the flowering period, typically by late spring, it's advisable to trim the plant lightly to encourage bushier growth and more blooms in the next season. Avoid heavy pruning as it can affect flowering. Regularly remove any dead, diseased, or damaged stems to maintain plant health. Pruning is also an opportunity to shape the plant to your preference, although this hardy plant often maintains a neat shape naturally without much intervention."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"western moss-heather","description":"Cassiope mertensiana is a species of flowering plant known by the common names western moss heather and white mountain heather.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["western moss-heather"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Cassiope mertensiana"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10974,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Trichoglossum hirsutum, commonly known as the \"Hairy Earth Tongue\", typically inhabits moist, forested environments where natural leaf litter retains sufficient moisture. In a cultivated setting, maintain the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. Water the plant regularly to replicate its natural habitat's conditions, ensuring good drainage to prevent root rot. Avoid letting the substrate dry out completely as these fungi thrive in moist conditions. Misting can help increase humidity, but it's crucial to avoid excessive water that may lead to fungal overgrowth detrimental to its survival."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Trichoglossum hirsutum thrives in low-light conditions because it is often found on the forest floor, shaded by canopy cover. It does not require direct sunlight and should be shielded from strong, direct rays which can dry out the substrate and damage the delicate fungal structures. Instead, place it in an area that receives dappled light or consistent indirect exposure. Artificial lighting that mimics its natural habitat's low-light conditions can suffice if cultivating indoors, ensuring balanced light without the intensity."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not a typical practice for fungi such as Trichoglossum hirsutum. As fungi naturally decay and break down, removing dead or decaying fruiting bodies can be beneficial to maintain a clean environment. This minimizes the risk of diseases or pests and allows for the optimal growth of fresh fruiting bodies. Since these fungi arise from underground networks, ensuring the substrate remains undisturbed is more crucial than pruning. Regularly inspect your patch to manage any unwanted growths or decaying matter."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Hairy Earthtongue","description":"Trichoglossum hirsutum is a species of fungi in the family Geoglossaceae. They are commonly called black earth tongues.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America","Europe"],"other_name":["Hairy Earthtongue"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Trichoglossum hirsutum"],"soil":["Acidic","Humus-rich"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10279,"attracts":["Bees","Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Betula lenta, commonly known as sweet birch, prefers consistently moist but well-drained soil, especially when it is young and establishing. Regular watering is vital during the dry spells or drought periods to prevent stress. It's ideal to allow the top inch of soil to dry out slightly between watering sessions to avoid waterlogging and root rot. Established trees are more drought-tolerant but still benefit from occasional deep watering during prolonged dry periods to maintain leaf and overall plant health. Using mulch around the base helps retain moisture, reducing the need for frequent watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Betula lenta thrives best in full sun, requiring at least 6 hours of direct sunlight each day. However, it can also tolerate partial shade, especially in hot climates where some shelter from the midday sun might be beneficial to prevent leaf scorch. Placing it in a site that receives morning sun and some afternoon shade can be effective in such areas. Adequate sunlight helps maintain its vibrant leaf color and supports strong growth. Providing enough sun exposure also aids in the tree's resistance against certain diseases and improves its overall aesthetics."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Betula lenta should primarily be done in late winter or early spring before the new growth begins. This timing helps minimize sap loss and stress on the tree. Focus on removing any dead, damaged, or crossing branches to improve air circulation and sunlight penetration, which will promote healthy growth. Be careful not to over-prune as birches can be sensitive to heavy pruning. Additionally, remove low-growing branches to maintain a desired shape or to clear pathways. The soil should be kept slightly damp, but not waterlogged, as excessive moisture might lead to root rot. Always check the top inch of soil before watering again to determine if it has dried sufficiently."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cardamine hirsuta grows best in conditions ranging from full sun to partial shade. In regions with hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade can help prevent stress and leaf burn. If grown in too much shade, the plant may become leggy, seeking more light. Therefore, adjusting its exposure according to the climate conditions will ensure its robust growth and flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Cardamine hirsuta is not typically necessary unless for aesthetic purposes or to control spreading. To manage its growth, you can trim back any overly tall or leggy stems after its flowering phase in early spring. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10882,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Laurus nobilis, commonly known as bay laurel, prefers moderate watering. Allow the top one to two inches of soil to dry out between watering sessions. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it's important to ensure the soil drains well. In summer, you might need to water more frequently, especially if the plant is actively growing. During the winter months, reduce the amount of water provided as the plant's growth slows down. Always check for signs of underwatering, such as wilting leaves, and adjust your watering schedule accordingly."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Laurus nobilis thrives best in bright, indirect light. It can tolerate a few hours of direct sunlight each day, preferably in the morning or late afternoon, but too much direct sunlight can scorch the leaves. If growing indoors, placing the plant near a sunny window that provides dappled light is ideal. In regions with mild climates, bay laurel can be grown outdoors, where it should be positioned to receive indirect sunlight or partial shade, especially during the intense midday sun. Be mindful to rotate the plant occasionally to ensure uniform growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Laurus nobilis is essential to maintain its shape and encourage bushy growth. The best time to prune is in the late spring or early summer after the plant has finished flowering. Use clean, sharp shears to remove dead, damaged, or crossing branches to improve air circulation and light penetration. Trim back any overly long shoots to your desired shape, but avoid cutting too much at once, as this can stress the plant. Regularly removing the tips of branches can also promote denser growth, resulting in a fuller, healthier plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Bay laurel","description":"Laurus nobilis is an aromatic evergreen tree or large shrub with green, glabrous leaves, in the flowering plant family Lauraceae. It is native to the Mediterranean region and is used as bay leaf for seasoning in cooking. Its common names include bay laurel, sweet bay, bay (esp. United Kingdom),:84 true laurel, Grecian laurel, laurel tree or simply laurel. Laurus nobilis figures prominently in classical Greek, Roman, and Biblical culture.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mediterranean"],"other_name":["Bay laurel"],"pest_susceptibility":["Scale insects","Mealybugs"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Laurus nobilis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It's important to keep the soil consistently moist during its growing season, which typically spans spring and early summer. However, the plant is drought-tolerant once established and does not require frequent watering. Allow the top inch of soil to dry out between watering sessions to prevent overwatering and root rot. During the winter months, reduce watering as the plant's growth slows down. Always ensure good drainage to avoid waterlogged conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Leptosiphon parviflorus thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. Ideally, it should receive at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight per day for optimum growth and flowering. However, in hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade can protect the plant from excessive heat and stress. Too much shade, on the other hand, may result in leggy growth and fewer flowers. Adjust the location as needed to balance light exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Leptosiphon parviflorus should be minimal. The plant naturally grows in a compact form, and excessive pruning can disrupt its natural shape and flowering process. Generally, pruning is limited to removing any dead or diseased stems to encourage healthy growth. This should be done in the late winter or early spring before new growth starts. Deadheading spent flowers can promote further blooming but is not strictly necessary unless for aesthetic reasons. Ensure all cutting tools are sharp and sterilized to prevent disease transmission."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"variable linanthus","description":"Leptosiphon parviflorus (syn. These mushrooms do not require direct watering as they typically thrive in environments with natural moisture. If cultivating them, ensure the substrate remains damp but not overly saturated. Mist the growth area lightly to maintain humidity. Avoid pooling water, as excessive moisture can lead to rot or fungal imbalances. Keep the surrounding environment well-ventilated to prevent standing moisture, which can encourage unwanted mold growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Hygrocybe coccinea does not require direct sunlight as it naturally grows in shaded or lightly filtered lit areas within grassy meadows and forest clearings. They flourish best under indirect light, similar to the dappled light through trees. When artificially cultivating these mushrooms, maintain similar low-light conditions to mimic their natural habitat. Avoid exposing them to full sunlight as it may dry out the substrate and hinder their growth. Providing a balanced environment with moderate light helps support their development and growth cycles."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not applicable for Hygrocybe coccinea as it is a type of mushroom and not a plant with branches or leaves that require regular trimming. However, when cultivating mushrooms like the scarlet hood, it’s important to harvest them at the right time, which can be akin to pruning in plant care. Harvest them when their caps are fully expanded, but before they start to decay or become infested with insects, to encourage healthier future growth cycles and ensure the mushrooms remain in good condition."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":"Scarlet Waxy Cap","description":"Hygrocybe coccinea, sometimes called the scarlet hood, scarlet waxcap or righteous red waxy cap, is a colourful member of the mushroom genus Hygrocybe. These waxcaps are found across the Northern Hemisphere from China and Japan to Europe and North America. The small bright red mushroom is a familiar sight in unimproved grasslands in Europe in late summer and autumn, and woodlands in North America in winter.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"High","origin":["Europe","North America"],"other_name":["Scarlet Waxy Cap"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["November"],"scientific_name":["Hygrocybe coccinea"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Use distilled or rainwater to prevent mineral buildup as this plant is sensitive to high mineral content found in tap water. It's important not to let the soil dry out completely, as this can harm the plant. During winter, reduce watering slightly, but ensure the soil remains moist. Use a tray to provide a constant water source by maintaining a shallow layer of water around the pot, especially in warmer months."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Drosera rotundifolia thrives in full sunlight and requires a significant amount of light to grow well. Placing the plant in a location where it receives at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight daily will encourage vigorous growth and enhance its natural coloring. Indoors, a south-facing window or a sunroom works best. If natural sunlight is insufficient, especially during the shorter winter days, consider using grow lights to supplement. However, ensure the plant is not subjected to extreme heat as this can lead to drying out or scorch damage. Adjust lighting as necessary to maintain plant health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Drosera rotundifolia is minimal but beneficial for plant health and appearance. Regularly remove dead or dying leaves to prevent fungal infections and to keep the plant looking tidy. Use sterilized scissors or pruning shears to trim off dead foliage carefully. Dead flower stalks should also be removed to channel energy back into the plant. During the dormant winter period, the plant may naturally get rid of some leaves. Pruning at this time should be even more minimal, focusing only on obviously dead material. Always take care not to damage the healthy parts of the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"round-leaved sundew","description":"Drosera rotundifolia — the round-leaved sundew or common sundew — is a species of sundew, a carnivorous plant often found in bogs, marshes and fens. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11182,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Acer campestre, also known as the field maple, thrives in moist soil conditions but is relatively drought-tolerant once established. It is advisable to water the tree deeply and infrequently rather than lightly and frequently to encourage deep root growth. During periods of prolonged drought, supplemental watering may be necessary, especially in sandy soils or lighter, well-draining locations. Make sure the soil around the tree remains moist but not waterlogged to prevent root rot. It's particularly important to monitor the moisture levels in young trees to ensure they establish well in their new location."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Acer campestre performs well in a variety of lighting conditions, but it prefers full sun to partial shade. It is versatile and can tolerate some shade, although its growth may be slower compared to when it is in full sun. The tree is adaptable and can grow in a range of light environments, making it suitable for planting under taller trees where light may be dappled. When positioning your Acer campestre, try to ensure it receives at least six hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal growth and development, keeping in mind that some afternoon shade can help in hotter climates."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Acer campestre should preferably be done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Regular pruning helps maintain its shape and encourages healthy growth. Remove any dead, diseased, or damaged branches first. You can also thin out dense areas to allow light and air to penetrate the canopy. Consider lightly trimming branch tips to maintain the desired size and shape. Avoid excessive pruning as this can stress the tree and make it more susceptible to diseases. Ensure that all cuts are clean and made just above a bud or branch to encourage proper healing."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"field maple","description":"Acer campestre, known as the field maple, is a flowering plant species in the soapberry and lychee family Sapindaceae. It is native to much of Europe, the British Isles, southwest Asia from Turkey to the Caucasus, and north Africa in the Atlas Mountains. It has been widely planted, and is introduced outside its native range in Europe and areas of USA and Western Australia with suitable climate.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","Western Asia","North Africa"],"other_name":["field maple"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Acer campestre"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Clay","Chalky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It is important to water young trees regularly, especially during dry spells, to ensure their root systems develop well. Water deeply once a week, providing enough water to reach the roots. For mature trees, natural rainfall is usually sufficient, but during extended dry periods, supplement with deep watering every couple of weeks to keep the tree healthy and thriving."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Silver Maple trees prefer full sun to partial shade, thriving best with at least 4-6 hours of direct sunlight per day. While they are tolerant of a range of light conditions, ample sunlight encourages the healthiest growth and leaf development. If planted in too much shade, the tree may become leggy and prone to disease. Ensure the planting location allows for adequate sunlight exposure throughout the day, particularly in the morning and early afternoon, to maximize the tree's growth potential and overall health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Acer saccharinum should be done in late winter or early spring when the tree is dormant. Focus on removing dead, damaged, or crossing branches to improve air circulation and shape the tree. Avoid heavy pruning, as Silver Maples can respond with vigorous new growth that is often weaker. Regular maintenance with minor cuts to manage its growth and structure will help keep the tree healthy and reduce its tendency to get too large or unruly. Avoid pruning in the fall, as this may encourage new growth susceptible to winter damage."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"silver maple","description":"Acer saccharinum, commonly known as silver maple, creek maple, silverleaf maple, soft maple, large maple, water maple, swamp maple, or white maple—is a species of maple native to eastern and central North America in the eastern United States and Canada. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10379,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Dichelostemma capitatum, commonly known as blue dicks or wild hyacinth, is a drought-tolerant plant that requires minimal watering, especially once established. During its growing season in the fall and winter, it benefits from natural rainfall, but supplemental watering might be needed in dry periods. Ensure the soil is well-drained to prevent bulb rot. Water deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out somewhat between waterings. During the dormancy period in the summer, reduce or eliminate watering to mimic its natural habitat conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Dichelostemma capitatum thrives in full sun to part shade. It is adaptable but flourishes best with plenty of sunlight, which promotes vigorous growth and abundant blooms. If planted in an area with full sun exposure, ensure that the soil doesn't dry out too rapidly during active growth. In hotter regions, providing a bit of afternoon shade can help protect the plant from extreme heat stress. Ensuring at least 6 hours of sunlight per day will support the plant's growth and flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is minimal for Dichelostemma capitatum. After the blooming period, which typically occurs in early spring, allow the flower stalks to dry out naturally before removing them. This helps the plant to direct energy back to its corms for the next growing cycle. If desired, you can cut back the dried foliage in late summer. Be careful not to disturb the bulb during any pruning process. Regularly removing weeds and dead material around the base of the plant can also help maintain its health without the need for heavy pruning."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Blue Dicks","description":"Dichelostemma capitatum (syn. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11083,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Glechoma hederacea, commonly known as ground ivy, prefers consistent moisture. It thrives in soil that is kept evenly moist but not waterlogged. During the growing season, which is typically spring through fall, water the plant regularly to maintain slightly damp soil. Reduce watering in winter as the plant's growth slows down. Ensure good drainage to prevent root rot, but be mindful that the plant does not tolerate drought well. If the leaves begin to droop or yellow, it may be a sign of overwatering or underwatering, so adjusting your watering schedule accordingly is crucial."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Glechoma hederacea thrives best in partial shade to full sun. It can adapt to different lighting conditions, but grows most vigorously with bright, indirect sunlight. In direct sunlight, especially during hot summer afternoons, the leaves can become scorched; thus, providing dappled shade can be beneficial. If planted indoors, place it near windows where it can receive plenty of filtered light. In lower light conditions, the growth may become less dense and leggy, so optimizing for bright yet not overly harsh sunlight is ideal."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Glechoma hederacea is essential to manage its growth, as it can be quite invasive. Prune the plant regularly throughout the growing season to prevent it from overtaking other plants in your garden. Cutting back the stems by about one-third will encourage bushier growth and can help keep the plant compact and tidy. Deadheading, or removing spent flowers, can promote additional blooming. In late fall, a more substantial pruning can be done to prepare the plant for winter, removing any weak or leggy growth."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"ground-ivy","description":"Glechoma hederacea (syn. Nepeta glechoma Benth., Nepeta hederacea (L.) Trevir.) is an aromatic, perennial, evergreen creeper of the mint family Lamiaceae. It is commonly known as ground-ivy, gill-over-the-ground, creeping charlie, alehoof, tunhoof, catsfoot, field balm, and run-away-robin. It is also sometimes known as creeping jenny, but that name more commonly refers to Lysimachia nummularia. It has numerous medicinal uses, and is used as a salad green in many countries. European settlers carried it around the world,...","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Spring","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["ground-ivy"],"pest_susceptibility":["Anthracnose","Root rot"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Glechoma hederacea"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loam"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It is drought-tolerant once established and prefers well-drained soils. During its growing season, water the plant deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it is important to ensure proper drainage. In the summertime or during prolonged dry spells, occasional irrigation is necessary, but be careful not to let the soil remain soggy, as this plant is adapted to relatively dry conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Silver Lupine thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight per day to perform its best. It is ideally suited to bright, sunny locations that mimic its natural habitat. In regions with extremely hot summers, it may benefit from some afternoon shade to prevent scorching. However, too much shade can result in leggy growth and diminished flowering. When planting Lupinus albifrons, select a spot with good air circulation to help prevent fungal diseases, which can be more prevalent in areas with poor light and air flow."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lupinus albifrons involves deadheading spent flowers to encourage further blooming and prevent unwanted self-seeding. Once the flowering season is over, you can prune back the plant to remove any dead or unsightly stems. It is best to do this in late summer or early fall. Avoid heavy pruning in late fall or winter, as this plant can be sensitive to cold and might suffer damage if pruned too late in the year. Pruning helps maintain the plant's shape and encourages healthier, bushier growth the following season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Silver Bush Lupine","description":"Lupinus albifrons, silver lupine, white-leaf bush lupine, or evergreen lupine, is a species of lupine (lupin). It is native to California and Oregon, where it grows along the coast and in dry and open meadows, prairies and forest clearings. It is a member of several plant communities, including coastal sage scrub, chaparral, northern coastal scrub, foothill woodland, and yellow pine forest.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Silver-gray"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["California","Oregon"],"other_name":["Silver Bush Lupine"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["June"],"scientific_name":["Lupinus albifrons"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It thrives in conditions that mimic its natural habitat, so avoid overwatering to prevent compromising its delicate balance."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Umbilicaria mammulata thrives in environments where it receives moderate indirect sunlight. If you're growing it in a controlled environment, ensure it receives filtered light to mimic its natural habitat. Approximately four to six hours of diffused sunlight per day is optimal. Monitor the lighting conditions to make sure the lichen does not receive too much direct sun, which can lead to drying out and damage of the lichen thalli."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Umbilicaria mammulata is generally unnecessary due to its slow growth and small size. Since it is a lichen, it does not grow in a way that requires regular pruning like typical garden plants. However, if you are maintaining a collection of lichens or using them ornamentally, you may gently clean off debris or dead sections by hand as needed. Be very delicate, as lichens are easily damaged. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11381,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Rhododendron macrophyllum, commonly known as the Pacific rhododendron, requires regular watering to maintain moist but not waterlogged soil. It is essential to water deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry slightly between waterings. During the growing season, water it once or twice a week, depending on the weather and if the soil is well-drained. In winter, reduce watering frequency, as the plant is less active and requires less moisture. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and maintain a cooler root environment, which is beneficial for this plant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Rhododendron macrophyllum thrives in partial shade to dappled sunlight, as it is native to forested regions where it naturally grows under the canopy of taller trees. While it can tolerate some morning sunlight, it is best to avoid harsh afternoon sun, which can scorch the leaves. Ideally, provide filtered light or an area that receives a few hours of direct sunlight followed by shade. In hotter climates, more shade is advisable to protect the plant from intense heat, whereas in cooler climates, slightly more sun can be beneficial for robust growth and flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Rhododendron macrophyllum involves removing dead or damaged branches to maintain a healthy plant structure. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Lightly prune to shape the plant and increase air circulation, which helps prevent diseases. After flowering, you can also remove spent blooms (deadheading) to encourage new growth and more blooms the following season. Avoid heavy pruning as it can stress the plant and cause fewer blooms. Always use clean, sharp pruning tools to prevent damage and disease spread."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Pacific rhododendron","description":"Rhododendron macrophyllum, the Pacific rhododendron, California rosebay, California rhododendron, coast rhododendron or big leaf rhododendron, is a large-leaved species of Rhododendron native to the Pacific Coast of North America. It is important to keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. As the plant matures, it can tolerate short periods of drought, but for optimal growth and blooming, occasional deep watering during dry spells is beneficial. Always allow the topsoil to dry between waterings and reduce watering frequency during the fall and winter months when the plant is dormant and not actively growing."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Prunus cerasifera thrives in full sun, requiring at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day to achieve optimal flowering and fruiting. While it can tolerate partial shade, less sunlight may result in fewer blooms and slower growth. When selecting a site for planting, ensure that it is a location that receives ample sunlight throughout the day to support its growth habit and aesthetic qualities. In hot climates, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to protect the plant from scorching and heat stress."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Prunus cerasifera is best done in late winter or early spring, before the onset of vigorous new growth. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to maintain plant health and encourage air circulation. Thinning cuts can help reduce crowding in the canopy and enhance light penetration, promoting more blooms and fruit production. It may also be necessary to control the size and shape of the plant by selectively cutting back overgrown or crossing branches. Avoid excessive pruning as this can stress the plant and reduce flowering the following spring."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Cherry-plum","description":"Prunus cerasifera is a species of plum known by the common names cherry plum and myrobalan plum. It is native to Southeast Europe and Western Asia, and is naturalised in the British Isles and scattered locations in North America. Also naturalized in parts of SE Australia where it is considered to be a mildly invasive weed of bushland near urban centers.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["Cherry-plum"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Scale insects","Powdery mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Prunus cerasifera"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It's also helpful to pinch back the growing tips to encourage bushier growth and remove lower leaves to prevent them from touching the soil, which can help minimize the spread of soil-borne pathogens. Pruning can be done throughout the growing season as needed."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Bitter Melon","description":"Momordica charantia, known as bitter melon, bitter gourd, bitter squash, or balsam-pear, is a tropical and subtropical vine of the family Cucurbitaceae, widely grown in Asia, Africa, and the Caribbean for its edible fruit. Regular pruning can help keep the tree aesthetically pleasing and structurally sound."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Norway maple","description":"Acer platanoides (Norway maple) is a species of maple native to eastern and central Europe and western Asia, from France east to Russia, north to southern Scandinavia and southeast to northern Iran. Proper sunlight exposure also helps in preventing fungal diseases."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Castanea dentata should be done during the dormant season, typically in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, diseased, or damaged branches to maintain the tree's health. It's also advisable to thin out crowded areas to improve air circulation, which can help prevent diseases. Take care to make clean cuts and avoid cutting into the collar of the branches. Young trees may require formative pruning to establish a strong main trunk and desired growth habit, but mature trees generally require minimal pruning."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"American chestnut","description":"The American chestnut (Castanea dentata) is a large, monoecious deciduous tree of the beech family native to eastern North America. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11485,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Senecio flaccidus, commonly known as Threadleaf Groundsel, is a drought-tolerant plant native to arid regions. It requires minimal watering once established, typically once every two to four weeks, depending on environmental conditions. The key is to let the soil dry out completely between waterings, as this plant is highly susceptible to overwatering and root rot. During periods of active growth in spring and early summer, slightly more frequent watering may be beneficial, but always ensure that the pot or ground drainage is excellent. Reduce watering significantly in the fall and winter months."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Senecio flaccidus thrives in full sun, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. It is well-suited to both garden beds and containers, as long as it receives adequate sunlight. This plant can tolerate light shade, but its growth may be less vigorous, and it may produce fewer flowers. For optimal flowering and foliage development, place the plant in a location with ample sunlight. If grown indoors, ensure it is positioned near a south-facing window or provide supplemental grow lights to mimic its natural environment."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Senecio flaccidus is generally done to maintain its shape, control its size, and remove any dead or damaged stems. The best time to prune is in early spring before new growth begins. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to cut back the plant, focusing on any overgrown branches or those that disrupt the desired shape. Light pruning can also be done throughout the growing season to remove any spent flowers or encourage bushier growth. Avoid cutting too much at one time, which can stress the plant."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"threadleaf groundsel","description":"Senecio flaccidus, formerly recorded as Senecio douglasii (in honor of the botanist David Douglas) member of the daisy family and genus Senecio also known as threadleaf ragwort (and threadleaf groundsel, bush senecio, creek senecio, shrubby butterweed, comb butterweed, smooth threadleaf ragwort, Mono ragwort, Douglas ragwort, Douglas groundsel, sand wash groundsel, felty groundsel, old man, yerba cana, squawweed or cenicillo) is a native of the southwestern Great Plains of North America.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["threadleaf groundsel"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Senecio flaccidus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Instead, it thrives when floating freely on the water surface in ponds, lakes, or water gardens. It absorbs nutrients from the water, so ensure the environment is nutrient-rich for optimal growth. If grown in small containers, refresh the water regularly to maintain its health. Avoid letting the plant dry out, as consistent access to water is crucial for its survival and vibrant appearance."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Eichhornia crassipes thrives best in full sunlight, needing at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth and flowering. However, it can tolerate partial shade as long as it receives sufficient bright, indirect light. In shaded conditions, it may produce fewer flowers and exhibit slower growth. Monitor the light exposure and adjust the plant's location in the water garden as necessary to ensure it receives enough sunlight without risking sunburn or overheating, especially in extremely hot climates."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Eichhornia crassipes is essential to prevent overgrowth and maintain balance in aquatic environments, as it can spread rapidly. Regularly remove dead or decaying leaves and flowers to promote healthy growth. Additionally, thin out dense clusters to allow adequate sunlight and nutrient circulation. Pruning should be done by simply cutting or pinching off unwanted parts close to the plant's base. Dispose of removed plant material responsibly, as improper disposal can lead to invasive growth in other water bodies."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"common water hyacinth","description":"Eichhornia crassipes, commonly known as (common) water hyacinth, is an aquatic plant native to the Amazon basin, and is often a highly problematic invasive species outside its native range.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"High","origin":["Amazon Basin","South America"],"other_name":["common water hyacinth"],"pest_susceptibility":["Spider mites","Water snails"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Eichhornia crassipes"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It prefers low to moderate light and should be placed in an environment with indirect sunlight to mimic dappled light conditions found under a canopy. Direct sun can harm the plant; hence, positioning it in a shaded area is crucial. Providing a setting that balances light with a cool, humid environment will support its growth and development, while ensuring the light levels are not too intense or direct."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Cephalanthera austiniae is generally minimal, as it is a rare and delicate orchid with specific ecological requirements. If necessary, remove any dead or damaged leaves to encourage healthy growth and prevent disease. Since it relies on a fungal relationship, disturbing the plant or soil can be detrimental. Focus more on maintaining its growing conditions rather than frequent pruning. It's best to let the plant's natural lifecycle proceed without interference unless absolutely necessary, ensuring it remains vigorous and healthy."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Phantom Orchid","description":"Cephalanthera austiniae is a species of orchid known by the common names phantom orchid and snow orchid because the entire plant is white except for a few yellow markings on the flowers.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Phantom Orchid"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Cephalanthera austiniae"],"soil":["Moist","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It is essential to keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. Water the plant when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. Be cautious not to overwater, as this can lead to root rot. Always use well-draining soil to prevent water accumulation around the roots. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and reduce the watering needs."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Physalis angulata thrives in full sunlight and requires at least six hours of direct sunlight per day for optimum growth. It can tolerate partial shade, especially during the hottest part of the day, but prolonged shading may affect fruit production and overall plant health. If grown indoors or in areas with limited natural light, consider using a grow light to supplement the plant's sunlight needs. Position outdoor plants in a location with southern or western exposure to ensure they receive ample direct sunlight throughout the day."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is beneficial for Physalis angulata as it encourages bushier growth and aids in removing unhealthy parts of the plant. Begin by removing any dead, diseased, or damaged stems as you notice them. Trim back any overgrown branches to maintain the plant's shape and promote air circulation. The best time to prune is during its growing season, usually in the spring or early summer. Regular pruning after the harvest can also enhance the plant's vitality. Use sharp and sanitized pruning shears to make clean cuts and prevent disease spread."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"cutleaf groundcherry","description":"Physalis angulata is an erect, herbaceous, annual plant belonging to the nightshade family Solanaceae. It reproduces by seed. Its leaves are dark green and roughly oval, often with tooth shapes around the edge. The flowers are five-sided and pale yellow; the yellow-orange fruits are born inside a balloon-like calyx. It is native to the Americas, but is now widely distributed and naturalized in tropical and subtropical regions worldwide.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Orange\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Central America","South America"],"other_name":["cutleaf groundcherry"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Physalis angulata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

However, be cautious of overwatering, as excessive moisture can lead to root rot and other issues related to poor drainage."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cochlearia officinalis thrives best in full sun to partial shade environments. It benefits from receiving at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight per day, which promotes healthy growth and flowering. In hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade can help prevent the leaves from scorching and protect the plant from heat stress. If grown indoors or in a shaded area, ensure it receives bright, indirect light to mimic its natural habitat. Adequate sunlight exposure boosts its nutrient content, especially when grown for its scurvy-prevention properties."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Cochlearia officinalis is generally minimal but can help maintain its health and appearance. Remove any dead or diseased leaves promptly to prevent the spread of disease. You can also trim back leggy or overgrown stems to encourage bushier growth. If you are cultivating it for its edible leaves, periodic harvesting acts as a form of pruning, promoting new growth and preventing the plant from becoming too woody. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to minimize damage to the plant, and prune in the early morning or late afternoon to avoid stress."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Scurvy grass","description":"Cochlearia officinalis, (or Common Scurvygrass, 'scurvy-grass' and 'spoonwort') is a flowering plant of the genus Cochlearia in the family Brassicaceae. Its very bitter taste was usually disguised with herbs and spices; however, this did not prevent scurvygrass drinks and sandwiches becoming a popular fad in the UK until the middle...","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":"Spring","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["Scurvy grass"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["June"],"scientific_name":["Cochlearia officinalis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10583,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Athyrium filix-femina, commonly known as the lady fern, requires consistently moist but not waterlogged soil. It thrives in environments where the soil is kept evenly moist, so regular watering is essential, especially during dry spells. During the growing season, ensure the soil never dries out completely. However, be cautious not to overwater, as soggy soil can lead to root rot. A good practice is to water the plant when the top inch of the soil feels dry to the touch. Reducing the frequency of watering during the dormant winter months is advisable."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lady fern prefers partial to full shade conditions, making it an excellent choice for woodland gardens or shaded corners where many other plants may struggle. It can tolerate some morning sun, but harsh afternoon sun can scorch its delicate fronds. The ideal location would provide dappled sunlight, reflecting its natural habitat under a canopy of trees. If planted in a region with intense sunlight, ensure it receives protection or additional shading to prevent the fronds from burning and to keep the soil from drying out too quickly."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning the lady fern involves removing old or damaged fronds to maintain the plant's health and appearance. In early spring, prior to new growth, carefully cut back dead or withered fronds close to the base. This encourages new fronds to develop and improves air circulation within the plant. Throughout the growing season, you can remove any fronds that appear brown or tattered. This not only keeps the fern looking tidy but also helps prevent disease. Always use clean, sharp pruning tools to avoid transmitting infections."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"lady fern","description":"Athyrium filix-femina, the lady fern or common lady-fern, is a large, feathery species of fern native throughout most of the temperate Northern Hemisphere, where it is often abundant (one of the more common ferns) in damp, shady woodland environments and is often grown for decoration.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","Asia","North America"],"other_name":["lady fern"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Division","Spores"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Athyrium filix-femina"],"soil":["Humus-rich","Well-drained","Moist"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

In winter, reduce watering frequency, allowing the soil to dry out a bit more between waterings, as the plant's growth slows down."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Aucuba japonica thrives in partial to full shade, making it an ideal plant for spots with limited sunlight. In overly bright conditions, the plant may develop leaf spots or lose its vibrant color, while too little light can slow its growth and reduce foliage density."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Aucuba japonica should be done in early spring just before new growth starts. When pruning, maintain the plant's natural form without cutting back too drastically. Occasionally thinning out dense areas helps to improve air circulation within the foliage. Regular pruning encourages bushier growth and helps maintain an aesthetically pleasing shape. Always use clean, sharp pruning tools to avoid causing distress to the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Japanese aucuba","description":"Aucuba japonica, commonly called spotted laurel, Japanese laurel, Japanese aucuba or gold dust plant (U.S.), is a shrub (1–5 m, 3.3–16.4 ft) native to rich forest soils of moist valleys, thickets, by streams and near shaded moist rocks in China, Korea, and Japan. This is the species of Aucuba commonly seen in gardens - often in variegated form. The leaves are opposite, broad lanceolate, 5–8 cm (2.0–3.1 in) long and 2–5 cm (0.79–1.97 in) wide. Aucuba japonica are dioecious. The flowers are...","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Japan","Korea","China"],"other_name":["Japanese aucuba"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Aucuba japonica"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

While it does not require frequent pruning, keeping the plant clean will help maintain an optimal growth environment and improve its overall health and appearance."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"California asterella","description":"Asterella californica is a complex thallic liverwort in the phylum Marchantiophyta. A. california often grows as colonies of flat rosettes of light green, rigid thalli, with undersides dark wine-red to nearly black. The receptacles are rounded, with four lobes each bearing a single sporangium sheathed by a white tattered skirt. A. california is dioecious with separate male plants often intermingled with female plants. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12081,"attracts":["bees","butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lysimachia vulgaris, commonly known as Yellow Loosestrife, prefers consistently moist soil, much like its natural habitat along water bodies. It's important to ensure that the plant is watered regularly, especially during dry spells or hot weather. Mulching can help retain soil moisture, but be cautious not to overwater, as waterlogged conditions can lead to root rot. During the summer, the plant may require more frequent watering to keep the soil damp."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Yellow Loosestrife thrives best in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive around 4 to 6 hours of sunlight daily. In regions with intense afternoon sun, it may benefit from some dappled shade to prevent leaf scorch. However, too much shade can lead to leggy growth and reduced flowering. Therefore, a balance of morning sun with some afternoon shade can help it grow optimally while maintaining its vibrant blooms."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lysimachia vulgaris is beneficial to maintain its shape and encourage bushier growth. After the flowering season in late summer or early fall, cut back the stems to just above the ground level. This practice not only tidies up the plant but also helps prevent the spread of seeds, which can help in managing its potential invasiveness. Regularly deadheading spent flowers can also promote prolonged blooming throughout the season."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Yellow Loosestrife","description":"Lysimachia vulgaris, the yellow loosestrife or garden loosestrife, is a species of herbaceous perennial flowering plants in the family Primulaceae. It is native to wetlands, damp meadows and forests of south-east Europe. It is a tall plant with an upright habit, 50–150 centimetres (20–59 in) high, with erect panicles of conspicuous yellow flowers.:519 The edges of the petals lack the fringe of hairs seen in L. punctata, and the hairy sepals have a conspicuous orange margin. :114","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["Yellow Loosestrife"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Lysimachia vulgaris"],"soil":["Well-drained","Moist","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Typically, watering every two to three weeks is sufficient, but this may vary based on the climate and season. Ensure the pot or garden bed has good drainage. Ideally, it should receive at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. If growing indoors, place the plant near a south or west-facing window to ensure it gets adequate light. Insufficient light can lead to leggy growth and pale leaves. However, it can tolerate partial shade, but optimal growth and flowering occur with ample sunlight."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Yucca glauca is relatively simple and is mainly for maintaining its shape and removing dead or damaged leaves. Prune in early spring before new growth begins. Using sharp, clean shears, cut away any yellow or brown leaves at the base, as well as any flower stalks after they have withered. Removing dead leaves not only improves its appearance but also prevents potential disease. Be cautious when handling the plant, as the leaves are sharp and can cause injury."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Great Plains yucca","description":"Yucca glauca (syn. Plant them in a location with full exposure to sunlight to ensure they develop robust foliage and a healthy crop yield. While they can tolerate partial shade, too much shade will result in reduced flowering and nut yield. Ensure the site is also sheltered from strong winds, which can damage the foliage and affect the tree’s overall health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Chinese chestnut trees is essential for maintaining their shape, health, and productivity. It's best done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to prevent the spread of pathogens. Ensure the tree maintains a strong central leader and an open, balanced structure for optimal growth and nut production."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Chinese chestnut","description":"Castanea mollissima (Chinese: 板栗; pinyin: bǎnlì), also known as the Chinese chestnut, is a member of the family Fagaceae, and a species of chestnut native to China, Taiwan, and Korea.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["China"],"other_name":["Chinese chestnut"],"pest_susceptibility":["Chestnut blight"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Grafting Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Castanea mollissima"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11987,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Oryza sativa, commonly known as rice, requires consistent and plentiful water as it typically grows in flooded conditions in paddy fields. It's crucial to maintain moisture, especially during the growth and tillering stages. During peak growing times, it may need daily watering to maintain adequate soil moisture levels. Withholding water only when the plant approaches harvest maturity is essential, where a slight drying can facilitate the drying and harvesting process."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Oryza sativa thrives best in full sunlight, requiring at least six to eight hours of direct and unobstructed sunlight each day. All parts of the plant contain a resin called urushiol that causes skin and mucous membrane irritation to humans. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10382,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Corallorhiza striata, commonly known as the striped coral root orchid, doesn't require active watering because it is a mycoheterotrophic plant. This means it derives nutrients from fungi in the soil rather than photosynthesis. It typically thrives in moist, rich, well-draining soil often found in forested areas. If cultivated in a garden setting, ensure the surrounding soil is consistently moist but not waterlogged. Mulching can help maintain soil moisture without overwatering. Excessive moisture can harm its delicate roots, so maintain just the right balance to support its symbiotic fungal relationships."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Corallorhiza striata prefers dappled or partial shade typical of its native forest habitats. It thrives under the canopy of trees where direct sunlight is filtered and indirect. Full sun can be damaging, as this plant is adapted to low-light conditions under forest canopies. If grown in a garden, position it in a shaded area that receives some indirect light, perhaps near shrubs or under taller plants. Mimicking the light conditions of a forest understory is crucial to its successful growth. Providing too much sunlight can lead to stress or damage, inhibiting its growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Corallorhiza striata does not require traditional pruning. As a non-photosynthetic orchid, it relies on its subterranean parts for nutrient absorption. Thus, pruning should be minimal and focused only on removing dead or decayed flower stalks after they have naturally withered. Avoid cutting any of the plant when it is actively blooming as this can interfere with its growth cycle. Instead, allow the stalks to naturally decompose and return nutrients back into the soil, supporting the plant's natural lifecycle and ecological relationships."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Striped Coralroot","description":"Corallorhiza striata is a species of orchid known by the common names striped coralroot and hooded coralroot. This flowering plant is widespread across much of southern Canada, the northern and western United States, and Mexico. It lives in dry, decaying plant matter on the ground in pine and mixed coniferous forests, and it obtains its nutrients from fungi via mycoheterotrophy.","family":null,"flower_color":"Red-brown","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Striped Coralroot"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Corallorhiza striata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Water it frequently during the growing season, keeping the substrate slightly damp, especially in warm conditions. Misting the leaves can help maintain humidity, but ensure good air circulation to prevent leaf rot. During winter, when growth slows, reduce watering frequency but do not allow the roots to dry out completely. A well-draining mix is important to prevent root rot, so ensure pots have drainage holes and use a potting mix suitable for epiphytic orchids."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Vanilla planifolia thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. It requires ample light for optimal growth and blooming but should be protected from direct sun exposure, which can burn the leaves. Filtered light through a sheer curtain or partial shading in a greenhouse would work well. In low light conditions, growth may slow, and flowering could be reduced, so aim for a warm, bright spot. If growing indoors, placing near an east- or west-facing window can provide sufficient light. Adjust the light exposure according to seasonal changes to maintain healthy growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Vanilla planifolia involves removing dead or damaged leaves and spent flower spikes post-blooming. Regularly check for and prune any discolored or unhealthy-looking sections of the vine to prevent disease spread. Keep the vine's growth in check by trimming long stems to encourage bushier growth and more manageable size, but avoid removing too many green leaves as this may reduce photosynthesis. Always use sterilized tools to prevent infection. Training the vine onto a sturdy support structure will help manage growth and improve air circulation."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":"Flat-leaved Vanilla","description":"Vanilla planifolia is a species of vanilla orchid. It is native to Mexico and Central America, and is one of the primary sources for vanilla flavouring, due to its high vanillin content. Common names are flat-leaved vanilla, Tahitian vanilla, and West Indian vanilla (also used for the Pompona vanilla, V. pompona). Often, it is simply referred to as \"the vanilla\". It was first scientifically named in 1808.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green to Yellow\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Winter","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"High","origin":["Mexico","Central America"],"other_name":["Flat-leaved Vanilla"],"pest_susceptibility":["Root rot","Mealybugs"],"propagation":["Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Vanilla planifolia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11185,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Tussilago farfara, commonly known as coltsfoot, prefers moderately moist soil, but it's quite tolerant of occasional dry spells once established. Keep the soil consistently moist during the growing season, but avoid overwatering to prevent root rot. Allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. In areas with regular rainfall, supplemental watering is only necessary during dry spells. As coltsfoot can thrive in a variety of soil types, adjusting the watering schedule based on specific soil conditions is recommended."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Tussilago farfara prefers full sun to partial shade for optimal growth. It thrives well under direct sunlight for most of the day but can also tolerate partial shade, especially in regions with high temperatures. If planted in an area with partial shade, ensure that it still receives at least four to six hours of sunlight daily to encourage flowering and prevent legginess. When grown in full sun, it will produce more abundant blooms. However, in particularly hot climates, providing some afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent the plant from overheating and to maintain the vibrancy of the foliage."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Tussilago farfara is relatively straightforward, as the plant does not require much maintenance. Deadhead the flowers as they fade to prevent unwanted self-seeding, as coltsfoot can spread aggressively. In early spring, cut back any dead or damaged foliage to make room for new growth. This also helps to maintain the plant's appearance and encourages healthier foliage. Be cautious while pruning, as the plant can become invasive; therefore, keeping the growth in check might involve removing unwanted shoots from spreading beyond the desired area regularly."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"colt's-foot","description":"Tussilago farfara, commonly known as coltsfoot,:770 is a plant in the groundsel tribe in the daisy family Asteraceae, native to Europe and parts of western and central Asia. The name \"tussilago\" is derived from the Latin tussis, meaning cough, and ago, meaning to cast or to act on. While Bermuda grass is adaptable and can tolerate partial shade, it will not grow as vigorously or densely in shaded areas.
